data.title: A Barcelona Guide to Each Neighborhood
data.meta_description: At a few months in Barcelona, Spain, I compiled a list of over 60 things to do in Barcelona and it's sectioned by each neighborhood.
data.text:
Barcelona, Spain‚Äôs second city, but first in my heart. This coastal wonderland has amazing food, a diverse population, and a relaxed atmosphere. I spent two months in Barcelona last spring/summer and got to see Barcelona from another perspective. From rooftop bars to iconic landmarks, this is all the best things to do in Barcelona.

This list is divided into different neighborhoods throughout Barcelona.

Gothic Quarter

The Gothic Quarter is the center of Barcelona and where the famous La Rambla street is located. This is a big tourist hub and therefore a prime spot for pickpockets. But not to fret, keep your valuables close to you while walking these busy streets, avoid distractions, and you should see no problem. There‚Äôs plenty to do and see so here are some of the best things to do in the Gothic Quarter, Barcelona.

Barcelona Cathedral

TIP: The entrance is free to the church each day from 10 am-noon. It‚Äôs just an additional 3‚Ç¨ to go to the rooftop

Hotel Col√≥n Rooftop

This is the best view of Barcelona cathedral! The view at the Barcelona Cathedral rooftop is beautiful but if you want a view of the cathedral itself go Hotel Col√≥n.

La Boqueria Mercat

This popular market is a must if you‚Äôre looking for fresh produce, meats and cheeses, spices, tapas, wine, and more!

Els 4 Gats

This Modernisme cafe was once frequented by Picasso and Guad√≠. Come for a coffee and stay for the architecture.

Erotic Museum

This is a bit of a tourist trap and definitely not for everyone but nonetheless a fun spot for anything with an open mind and sense of humor.

Eixample

Eixample is the Catalan word for ‚Äòexpansion‚Äô and was once another small suburb town. The city expanded over time and the neighborhood is now full of amazing shopping streets, restaurants, and some of Antoni Guad√≠‚Äôs most famous masterpieces.

Casa Batll√≥

Once of Guad√≠‚Äôs most famous buildings, Casa Batll√≥ welcomes guests year around. The average visit is about an hour. To avoid large crowds come early or an hour before close. Tickets can be purchased online.

Entrance 25‚Ç¨

La Pedrera (Casa Mil√°)

Another iconic Guad√≠ masterpiece, La Pedrera is a stunner. Visit the rooftop around golden hour for the best lighting.

Entrance 22‚Ç¨ (save 3‚Ç¨ when you book online)

Passeig de Gr√†cia

This street is famous for its shops and restaurants. From Adidas to Zara and everything in between, get your shop on at Passeig de Gr√†cia.

Sant Antoni

Sant Antoni is a small neighborhood that is part of the Eixample District (have I confused you yet?). It‚Äôs the area around the Sant Antoni metro and boarders Poblesec, El Raval, and the neighborhood of Eixample (not to be confused with the district, and if you‚Äôre confused, that‚Äôs okay!). It‚Äôs small but has it‚Äôs own marketplace, the main street that hosts festivals and there are some amazing restaurants.

Mercat de Sant Antoni

The Mercat de Sant Antoni is the neighborhood‚Äôs marketplace for produce, meats, and more. There are also ready to eat food stalls. And if you don‚Äôt find everything you need inside there‚Äôs a Lidl supermarket on the basement level.

S√©samo

S√©samo is an amazing vegetarian/vegan restaurant. They have a multi-course special that is delicious, at a great price, and includes wine!

Mercat del Llibre de Sant Antoni (Sant Antoni Book Market)

Open every Sunday 8:30 am ‚Äì 2:30 pm, this market is open to book lovers near and far. Score yourself used books at killer prices.

El Raval

El Raval is an interesting neighborhood, to say the least. This is where I lived during my 2-month stay in Barcelona and I got to see the good, the bad, and the ugly. It can be known as an unsafe area. Nothing bad had ever happened to me but I‚Äôve seen some stuff. Nonetheless, I had some amazing times there. It‚Äôs a multicultural city with a large population of immigrants from around the world. It also quite artsy as it‚Äôs home to MACBA (the modern art museum) and numerous galleries.

Palau G√ºell

Palau G√ºell is the former home of the G√ºell i L√≥pez family and one of the first important Antoni Gaud√≠ received in his early career. The multilevel home is stunning and full of beautiful details. The rooftop is a picture-perfect spot with amazing views of the city. Palau G√ºell hosts a free day each month, find out about all the free entrance days in Barcelona here.

Museu d‚ÄôArt Contemporani de Barcelona (MACBA)

MACBA is Barcelona‚Äôs contemporary art museum and a popular spot for skateboarders. Go to the museum, hang out, and watch people skating while having some tapas at one of the cafes.

Centre de Cultura Contempo√†nia de Barcelona (CCCB)

The CCCB is a cultural center that focuses on the challenges of contemporary society through different mediums. The CCCB also hosts film screenings, music events, and more.

Biblioteca de Catalunya

The Biblioteca de Catalunya is one of my favorite gems in El Raval. The library is a fun place to visit for all the bookworms. Then cheap out to the courtyard to hang out and get some fresh air. After, eat at El Jard√≠, an outdoor cafe that serves up amazing dishes.

El Jardi

As mentioned above, El Jardi‚Äôs outdoor space at the Biblioteca de Catalunya is quaint, romantic, and delicious. Come for dinner, drinks, or tapas.

Rambla del Raval

La Rambla de Raval is the neighborhood‚Äôs ‚Äúmain street.‚Äù It‚Äôs made up of lots of bars and restaurants and also home to the giant cat (El Gat de Botero).

Bars on Carrer de Joaqu√≠n Costa

Carrer de Joaqu√≠n Costa is full of lively bars, restaurants, local shops, and more! The nights bring in a crowd and the bars are usually packed. I recommend checking out 33/45 and Bar Manchester.

Pati Manning Bar

Pati Manning is a cultural center located next door to CCCB. Their bar which is more like a cafe is a great place to grab some coffee. Admire their tiled walls as you sit out in the charming courtyard.

360¬∫ at Hotel Barcel√≥ Raval

360¬∫ is a rooftop bar at the Hotel Barcel√≥ Raval with a (you guessed it) 360¬∫ view of Barcelona. Come enjoy the views of the beautiful city while sipping on your favorite cocktail. Check out my other blog post for more Barcelona rooftop bars.

Poble Sec

Poble Sec is one of Barcelona‚Äôs oldest neighborhoods dating back to Roman times. It‚Äôs located between Montj√ºic, the port, and Sant Antoni. It is a residential area however despite not being in the heart of the city center is still quite lively!

Jam Circus

Jam Circus is a cultural association that promotes the arts. Come in to check out unique entertainment including cool musical performances and more.

Carrer Blai

Carrer Blai is a street famously known for its tapas bars. It can be a bit touristy but not overcrowded. Bars and restaurants serve up tapas starting at 1‚Ç¨.

Parc de les Xemeneies

Come to Parc de les Xemeneies if you‚Äôre a fan of cool street art. It‚Äôs probably the best place to see street art that‚Äôs still walking distance from the city center. It‚Äôs also a skate park so come for the skateboarding or to check out the skaters at play.

Montj√ºic

Montj√ºic is a residential neighborhood set on the foothills. It‚Äôs home to some of Barcelona‚Äôs best attraction and its elevation makes for amazing views. The lush area is full of public gardens, museums, a castle, and more.

Fundaci√≥ Joan Mir√≥

The Fundaci√≥ Joan Mir√≥ is an art museum featuring some of Mir√≥‚Äôs works also with contemporary art pieces. It was created by Mir√≥ himself and designed by architect, Josep Llu√≠s Sert.

Restaurant La Font del Gat

La Font del Gat is a restaurant a stone throw away from Fundaci√≥ Joan Mir√≥. It has a lovely terrace that is surrounded by the Jardins de Laribal.

Jardins de Joan Maragall

Jardins de Joan Maragall is one of the lovely gardens of Montj√ºic. Entrance is free but do check the timetables as it is only open on the weekends and holidays.

Jardins de Mossen

If you‚Äôre a succulent lover head to Jardins de Mossen! The garden is Europe‚Äôs largest specializing in cacti and succulents. Come for the biodiversity and the views.

Montj√ºic Cemetery

For the ones who like things that are slightly creepy head to Montj√ºic cemetery. This cemetery is historic and full of amazing headstones, statues, mausoleums and more.

Olympic Stadium

Did you there‚Äôs an Olympic Stadium in Barcelona? Construction for the stadium began back in 1927 in preparation for the 1929 International Expo. Then it was renovated in 1989 for the 1992 Summer Olympics. It‚Äôs open for tours and there are special events such as concerts held here as well.

Montj√ºic Cable Car (Telef√®ric de Montju√Øc)

Once you‚Äôre at the top of Montj√ºic you can take the cable car for even more incredible views of the city. The Cable car has a midway stop at the Mirador station where you can get and visit the Mirador de l‚ÄôAlcald.

Magic Fountain of Montj√ºic

The Magic Fountain of Montj√ºic is a water, light and music show at the famous Montj√ºic Fountain. Shows take place on certain nights of the week depending on the season so it‚Äôs important to check the website to check showtimes.

Montj√ºic Castle (Castell de Montj√ºic)

At the top of Montj√ºic hill and just above the cable car entrance, lies Montj√ºic Castle. From up here, you can get a 360¬∫ view of the city. The castle has a long history dating back to the 1600s.

Museu Nacional d‚ÄôArt de Catalunya (MNAC)

Museu Nacional d‚ÄôArt de Catalunya is the national art museum and probably the grandest museum in the entire city. At the footsteps of the museum, you‚Äôll find the Magic Fountain of Montj√ºic. The museum is open every Tuesday ‚Äì Sunday.

Gr√†cia

Gr√†cia is one of the more local neighborhoods in Barcelona that is still close to the city center. It‚Äôs home to Park G√ºell, one of the most visited attractions in Barcelona. It used to be a completely separate city but as Barcelona grew it became a part of it. The neighborhood is full of life and culture. A visit to Gr√†cia is a must when coming to Barcelona.

Casa Vicens

Casa Vicens is Gaud√≠‚Äôs first masterpiece and still a slightly underrated attraction. The home was built for the Vicens family and is now open to the public. This home is an architectural marvel with so many intricate details.

TIP: regular admission is 16‚Ç¨ but on Mondays, it‚Äôs reduced to 10‚Ç¨ and there‚Äôs a free day on May 22, Santa Rita Day

Carrer Gran de G√†rcia

If you‚Äôre getting off the metro more than likely you‚Äôll walk onto Gran de Gr√†cia. This busy street is full of shops and is one of the main streets in the Gr√†cia neighborhood.

Pla√ßa Del Diamant

Pla√ßa Del Diamant is a local hot spot so if you want to hang with the locals, this is where to do it. This plaza is full of life, restaurants, terraces, and more! Gr√†cia has a long history and you can see a piece of it by visiting the former Spanish Civil War underground bomb shelters. You‚Äôll have to reserve in advance.

Park G√ºell

Park G√ºell is one of the most iconic attractions of Barcelona. This park is set at the top of a hill in the Gr√†cia neighborhood and offers amazing views. The park itself is free but the ‚Äúregulated zone‚Äù is by ticket only during opening hours.

TIP: enter the ‚Äúregulated zone‚Äù for free before the opening hours or after it closes.

Gr√†cia Latina

Gr√†cia Latina is a cozy bar that hosts amazing musical events including salsa, bachata, flamenco, and more!

Casa Gr√†cia

Casa Gr√†cia is an upscale hostel that hosts amazing events. Come for spoken word, comedy shows, and musical events in their downstairs ‚Äúvault-style‚Äù bar and in other spaces in the facility.

Poblenou

Poblenou is an up and coming neighborhood that is still quite industrial. It‚Äôs a lot quieter than other neighborhoods but has so much to offer. From the beach to the art, to the co-working spaces, Poblenou is the perfect place to work and play!

Poblenou Cemetery

This is the second cemetery on the list and I‚Äôm sure that might sound creepy to some but I promise you it‚Äôs mainly because of the history and architecture. This Neoclassical and Neo-Gothic cemetery has amazing things to see such as the ‚ÄúPet√≥ de la mort‚Äù (Kiss of Death) statue.

Street art

A visit to Poblenou isn‚Äôt complete without a street art tour. With abandoned spaces and redevelopment Poblenou has been a street artists‚Äô canvas. Take a self-tour around Parc del Centre del Poblenou

Bogatell Beach

Want to head to a nearby beach in Barcelona but want to get away from the street vendors and huge crowds? Head to Bogatell Beach!

Palo Alto Market

The Palo Alto Market is an outdoor cultural market that happened each first weekend of the month. Come for the food and drinks, and stay for the shopping and musical events.

El Clot

The El Clot neighborhood is small in size but is home to the largest flea market. It‚Äôs part of the Sant Mart√≠ district and close by the famous Sagrada Familia. It‚Äôs a great spot for shopping since it‚Äôs where the Centro Comercial Glories, big shopping mall is located.

Mercat Els Encants

Mercat Els Encants is Barcelona‚Äôs largest flea market and known worldwide. It‚Äôs open Monday, Wednesday, Friday, and Saturday 9 am ‚Äì 8 pm and there‚Äôs a public antique auction every Monday, Wednesday, and Friday from 8 am ‚Äì 9:30 am.

El Born

El Born is a trendy neighborhood with a booming nightlife. However, it‚Äôs not just an evening scene because there‚Äôs plenty to do and see. From leisurely walks in the park to have a tapas crawl, there‚Äôs something for everyone in El Born.

Museu Picasso

Museu Picasso is a museum dedicated to Picasso himself. Born in M√°laga, Spain but a resident of Barcelona for some time, Picasso‚Äôs art lives on. Many of the paintings were made here in Barcelona where you can see them on display.

Parc de la Ciutadella

Parc de la Ciutadella is one of my favorite parks. It‚Äôs absolutely a lovely place for a picnic. You can easily spend the day walking around or sunbathing.

Bars!

There‚Äôs no shortage of bars in El Born. With a vibrant nightlife, El Born is a great place to hang out and drink with friends. Walk down the Passeig del Born day or night for fun bars, food, and more.

Palau de la M√∫sica Catalana

The Palau de la M√∫sica Catalana is a stunning building. I recommend taking their guided tour and seeing the inside. Or you can also watch a performance there.

Mosquito Tapas

Mosquito Tapas is a cozy restaurant that serves up Asian tapas. They are defiantly one of my favorite non-Spanish tapas restaurants in Barcelona.

Arc de Triomf

There‚Äôs an Arc de Triomf in Barcelona? Yes, this landmark originally served as the gateway forth 1888 Universal Exhibition. Today it still stands tall in front of the Parc de la Ciutadella, ready for all the selfie-loving tourists üôÇ

Sagrada Familia

Sagrada Familia is a small neighborhood that welcomes millions of visitors each year to one of Barcelona‚Äôs most iconic landmarks.

Sagrada Familia

Sagrada Familia is stunning, the view from the park (plaza de Gaud√≠) across the way gives you a better view. The inside is beautiful but do book ahead of time so you don‚Äôt have to wait in any lines.

Sant Pau Recinte Modernista

Sant Pau Recinte Modernista was once a hospital and now a museum open to the public. It‚Äôs a bit under the radar since it isn‚Äôt so close to the city center. Visit this Modernisme wonder anytime or during one of their FREE entrance days.

Self-guided visit: 15 ‚Ç¨

Guided visit: 20 ‚Ç¨

Barceloneta

Barceloneta is the beloved beach neighborhood of Barcelona. It‚Äôs home to Barcelona Beach and Platja de Sant Sebasti√†, the W Hotel, the port, and so much more! Rain or shine, you‚Äôll always find people flocking to Barceloneta (but even more so on the sunny days for obvious reasons). Come for the tan lines and stay for a mojito on the beach.

Barceloneta Beach and Platja de Sant Sebasti√†

Barceloneta Beach and Platja de Sant Sebasti√† are the two closest beaches to the city center so they do get rather packed on sunny weather days. This busy beach gets very busy so plan accordingly!

Hotel Arts Rooftop bar

If you‚Äôre a fan of rooftop bars then Hotel Arts is not to be missed. With an infinity pool overlooking the beach, it‚Äôs the perfect place to watch the sunset while drinking a glass of cava.

Outside the city center

There‚Äôs so much to do outside the city center that you can still get to in less than an hour metro ride or bus ride. If you have more than a couple of days in Barcelona definitely visit at least one of the amazing places, beat the crowds of the city and enjoy!

Les Corts

The Les Corts neighborhood is where soccer dreams are made. If you‚Äôre a soccer fan then a visit here to Camp Nou is a must!

Camp Nou

Camp Nou is home to FC Barcelona, the world famous soccer club of Barcelona. Get a stadium tour at the Camp Nou Experience or come see Messi in action at a game.

Del Carmel

Bunkers del Carmel

Want a picture-perfect panoramic view of Barcelona? Head to Bunkers del Carmel! The once Spanish Civil War bunkers are now a place to see the city, watch the sunset, and sip wine with friends while doing it.

Tibidabo

‚ÄúYears ago I was backpacking across western Europe‚Ä¶.‚Äù If you‚Äôre a Friends fan then you totally caught the reference. Tibidabo is a wealthy neighborhood in Barcelona and more famously where Tibidabo Mountain is located. There‚Äôs a theme park, a mountain for hiking and biking, and wonderful views.

Hiking Tibidabo

Mount Tibidabo isn‚Äôt a strenuous hike by any means but there are tons of trails that will take you around and up top to the mountain. It‚Äôs a great place to get away from the busy city and be with nature.

Parc D‚ÄôAtraccions Tibidabo

Parc D‚ÄôAtraccions Tibidabo is an amusement park at the top of Mount Tibidabo. You can enter the panoramic portion of the park for free or if you‚Äôd like to stay in the get on the rides there are tickets for that as well.

Mirablau

Mirablau is a restaurant with a panorama view. You can sit inside near the windows or on the terrace.

Horta

Horta is another neighborhood that is away from the crowds. It is still well connected to the city center by metro so the commute isn‚Äôt very long.

Laberint d‚ÄôHorta

Want to get lost? The Laberint d‚ÄôHorta is a beautiful garden with a maze. You can walk around the gardens then head to the labyrinth to get a little lost. It‚Äôs also fun to people watch from the top of the stairs.

Free entrance on Wednesdays and Sundays

Regular admission 2.23‚Ç¨

I hope you enjoyed this ‚Äúthings to do in Barcelona‚Äù guide. If you want to save this list with over 60 things to do in Barcelona for later, please Pin it!
